Award.AwardTitle: Striving to Advance Teacher Education in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Noyce Capacity Building project at Mississippi State University (MSU) aims to build the knowledge, community, and partnerships needed to increase the number of students recruited into STEM teaching. It includes leadership of four MSU departments and the Starkville-Oktibbeha Consolidated School District, as well as mentoring by the principle investigator of the University of Kentucky's Track 1 Noyce program. The project is designed to analyze recruitment strategies, barriers to program retention, teacher candidates' demographics, and the characteristics of STEM teachers who have remained in STEM classrooms. By leveraging partnerships, the project seeks to broaden recruitment efforts, align positive teaching messages across Mississippi and university courses, and develop mentoring for undergraduate students from engineering, math, and sciences interested in becoming math and science teachers. The partnerships have the potential to enable the project team to reach and recruit a broader group of students to pursue STEM teacher education. Through research with in-service STEM teachers, including MSU alumni and other high-performing teachers, the project seeks to evaluate programmatic components that contribute to retention in the STEM teacher profession. This project aims to increase the number of students recruited into STEM teaching, develop a Noyce Track 1: Scholarships and Stipends proposal, and contribute to the literature on effective recruitment and retention of STEM education students.

The project intends to gather essential information on the successes and challenges faced in Mississippi, such as recruiting students into STEM education, retaining these students in STEM teacher education programs, and strengthening the partnerships of key stakeholder in STEM education. It is a collaborative Capacity Building project between MSU's Department of Curriculum, Instruction, and Special Education, College of Education, College of Arts and Sciences, and Department of Computer Science and Engineering, as well as Starkville-Oktibbeha Consolidated School District. The project is designed to benefit from a mentoring relationship with the existing University of Kentucky's Noyce Track 1 Scholarship and Stipends project. Coupling this effort with that of the University of Kentucky may strengthen the program, so that more undergraduate STEM majors gain licensure to teach mathematics, biology, chemistry, physics, and, computer science. This project will gather and analyze baseline data needed to understand how to foster recruitment and program retention that leads to STEM teacher certification, while enhancing existing partnerships to study policies, strategies, and programs for STEM education. New knowledge gained in Mississippi via this project may serve as a model for increasing STEM teacher education in southeastern universities, as well as in other universities across the nation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Capacity Building: StATE-STEM: Strengthening and Advancing Teacher Education in STEM built a  collaborative relationship between  Mississippi State University?s (MSU) Department of Curriculum, Instruction, and Special Education, College of Education Teacher Education program, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Department of Mathematics and Statistics, and collaborating Local Education Districts including Starkville-Oktibbeha Consolidated School District, West Point School District and Columbus School District. The goal of this cross-institutional and cross-college team was to gather and analyze recruitment strategies, barriers to program retention, teacher candidates? demographics including diversity of candidates, as well as the characteristics of STEM teachers who have remained in the classroom. Additionally, our team identified and met with other stakeholders across MSU and the state to help understand recruitment and the needs of our 7-12 education system.  Of particular significance was building a working relationship with our Academic Advising center which works with all undeclared undergraduate students.  Additionally, StATE STEM project team members collaborated with or developed presentations for the Mississippi Department of Education, the Mississippi Association of Mathematics Teacher Educators, and Mathematics Teacher Education Partnership.

Intellectual Merit: StATE STEM sought to analyze recruitment and retention strategies, broaden partnerships, and examine program characteristics to both reach and influence a broader group of students to pursue to completion STEM teacher education. Through efforts to better understand the successes and challenges of recruitment and retention, StATE STEM aimed to advance the current knowledge base of how to effectively recruit and retain students in STEM teacher education.

Through both collaboration with key stakeholders, surveying of current STEM education students, and experimenting with some recruitment events, the Co-PIs were able to glean useful information about the recruitment and retention process.  It is well documented that most students in education chose STEM teacher education rather than were recruited into it.  Our students report that while scholarships or tuition incentives are helpful, they did not influence them to major in STEM education. However, individual interactions, especially with MSU students, were key in having students chose MSU over other institutions.  The student interaction at recruitment events was also useful in making initial contact with students shopping for a major.  The project team observed that our student easily and successfully made initial contact and then would introduce them to a professor/advisor for more information. Facilitating student cohorts, especially early in the program, also aides in retaining students in STEM education. 

As a culminating event, StATE STEM had planned a Would Teaching Be for You? recruitment event for Spring 2020.  This event was designed after reviewing successful recruiting events, considering our own findings, and discussions with local teachers and students in mathematics education.  The event was targeted specific high school juniors identified by their mathematics or science teachers as potentially great teachers.  The project team posited increasing recruitment of underrepresented students would happen through individual invitation as opposed to general invitations to the recruitment event.  Collaborating mathematics teachers would accompany the students to MSU.  The mathematics education students were planning the day?s events.  Due to COVID-19, the event did not happen.  However, the event will be held during the 2020-2021 academic year.  Successes will be documented, and the project team will track whether these students choose STEM education with enrollment at MSU as a bonus.   

Broader Impact:  Mississippi is striving to improve mathematics and science education across the state. StATE STEM has the potential to increase the number of teachers produced by MSU by 10%, which will impact up to 1000 secondary students per year. Ultimately, improved student achievement means a better-prepared workforce. Through our collaboration with key stakeholders, the project team discovered that our program of study could be improved to better prepare and retain our STEM education students.  First, under the current design consistent interaction with students outside of advising does not occur until their junior year.  A newly developed sophomore-level course introducing STEM education as a potential career will be open to all MSU students. At the recommendation of both our mentor at the University of Kentucky and our local teachers, the Assessment course was redesigned.  The suggestions of the local teachers were integrated into the course.  Additionally, a cross-listed computer science course that emphasizes computer science within the context of education was developed.  This course is highly recommended as the education programming course and open to all computer science majors that might want to consider education. These programatic changes should better prepare STEM education teachers to enter and stay in the field.

The StATE STEM Co-PIs are sharing the results of this project in state and national research projects and committees.  Specifically, the PI is a collaborator on a research grant studying systemic transformation specific to mathematics education.  Co-PIs are also contributing to a national group examining recruitment and retention in mathematics education.
